metadata.titleEn: Meteorological observation data from Qomolangma station for atmospheric and environmental observation and research (2005-2016)
metadata.description: This data set includes the daily averages of the temperature, pressure, relative humidity, wind speed, precipitation, global radiation, P2.5 concentration and other meteorological elements observed by the Qomolangma Station for Atmospheric and Environmental Observation and Research from 2005 to 2016. The data are aimed to provide service for students and researchers engaged in meteorological research on the Tibetan Plateau. The precipitation data are observed by artificial rainfall barrel, the evaporation data are observed by Φ20 mm evaporating pan, and all the others are daily averages and ten-day means obtained after half hour observational data are processed. All the data are observed and collected in strict accordance with the Equipment Operating Specifications, and some obvious error data are eliminated when processing the generated data.

background: The Tibetan Plateau, with the most prominent and complicated terrain on the globe and an elevation averaging more than 4000 m above mean sea level (msl), is often called the “Third Pole” because its geographic significance is akin to that of Antarctica and the Arctic. The thermal effects of the giant plateau on the atmosphere greatly influence circulations over China, eastern Asia and even the globe. The plateau absorbs a large proportion of solar radiation (some of which is redistributed by cryospheric processes) and undergoes dramatic seasonal changes of surface heat and water fluxes. The lack of quantitative understanding of interactions between the land surface and atmosphere makes it difficult to understand and model the complete energy and water cycles over the Tibetan Plateau and their effects on global climate change. Therefore, the number of atmosphere-land interaction studies over the Tibetan Plateau has been increased in recent years.
research objective: The establishing and monitoring plan and the recent advances of the TORP will be introduced firstly in this paper. Then the preliminary observational analysis results, such as the characteristics of land surface heat fluxes and CO2 flux partitioning (diurnal variation, inter-monthly variation and inter-yearly variation etc.), the characteristics of atmospheric and soil variables, the structure of the Atmospheric Boundary Layer (ABL) and the turbulent characteristics will also be shown here.
challenges: The lack of quantitative understanding of interactions between the land surface and atmosphere makes it difficult to understand and model the complete energy and water cycles over the Tibetan Plateau and their effects on global climate change. But experiments have been limited to determine the land and atmospheric parameters, and most investigations have been only in summer and at a few locations.
dataset: The data collected by the TORP will be archived by the TORP data center in the ITP, CAS. The characteristics of the land surface heat fluxes and CO2 flux over the Tibetan Plateau area were derived by using in-situ data observed from the TORP. The characteristics of the atmospheric and soil variables over the Tibetan Plateau area were derived by using in-situ data observed from the TORP. The structure of the Atmospheric Boundary Layer (ABL) is analyzed by using the data observed from ABL tower, GPS radio-sonde system and Wind Profiler and RASS from the TORP. The characteristics of the atmospheric turbulent structure are analyzed by using the data observed from the sonic turbulent measurement system from the TORP.
findings: The results show that the diurnal variations of radiation fluxes (downward and upward shortwave radiation and upward long-wave radiation) and surface heat fluxes (net radiation flux, soil heat flux, sensible heat flux and latent heat flux) over the Tibetan Plateau area are very obvious clear, and the downward shortwave radiation are obvious larger than that in other areas due to the higher elevation and clear atmosphere over the Tibetan Plateau area. The diurnal variations of the turbulent fluxes are different during the dry period (pre-monsoon period) and wet period (inside monsoon period). The diurnal variation of momentum flux over the northern Tibetan Plateau area during the dry period is also obvious, increasing in the morning to its maximum in the afternoon, and then decreasing. Sensible heat flux H and latent heat flux LE vary by less than 10% of their magnitude with height over the flat prairie area of Naqu area of the northern Tibetan Plateau. The land surface is a very strong heating source in the day time, it is a weak surface heating sink in the night, but the daily mean is strong surface heating source. The diurnal variation of CO2 flux in summer is obvious over the alpine meadow surface of Mt. Everest area. The plateau ABL can extend to heights of almost 3 km above the ground surface in Naqu area of the northern Tibetan Plateau, and is characterized by a well-mixed layer of potential temperature. The convection over the Tibetan Plateau evolves from dry shallow convection in the morning to wet deep convection in the afternoon. The vertical gradients of potential temperature and humidity in the ABL of the Tibetan Plateau have an obvious sudden change in the middle of June.

background: The mountains of Himalayas are the important channels for the mass exchange between surface layer of Northern Hemisphere and troposphere atmosphere. The mountains relate surface layer atmosphere over the Tibetan Plateau and the above free atmosphere through many atmospheric circulation systems including mountain-valley wind and glacier wind etc. Mt. Qomolangma is the highest peak in the world, and its nearby region is a representative case of mountains of Himalayas.
research objective: Firstly the background of the establishment of the Atmospheric and Environmental Comprehensive Observation and Research Station on Mt. Qomolangma, Chinese Academy of Sciences (AECORSQ, CAS) and the role of the station in the study of the atmosphere-land interaction over Himalayas area was introduced in this paper.
findings: Then the preliminary observational analysis results, such as the characteristics of air temperature, pressure, air humidity, wind speed and wind direction, the structure of the Atmospheric Boundary Layer (ABL), the atmospheric turbulent characteristics and the energy exchange between the land surface and surface layer atmosphere, were shown.

background: The Tibetan Plateau contains the world’s highest elevation (average elevation about 4000 m) relief features, some reaching into the mid-troposphere. Because of its topographic character, the plateau surface absorbs a large amount of solar radiation energy, and undergoes dramatic seasonal changes of surface heat and water fluxes. Remote sensing from satellites however offers the possibility to derive regional distribution of surface heat fluxes over heterogeneous land surface of the Tibetan Plateau in combination with sparse field experimental stations. Regional distributions of surface heat flux (net radiation flux, soil heat flux, sensible heat flux and latent heat flux) have already been gotten by some researchers over the Tibetan Plateau area, but the results were only in meso-scale area till now.
research objective: In this study, a parameterization methodology based on MODIS (Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer) and in situ data is proposed and tested for deriving the regional surface reflectance, surface temperature, net radiation flux, soil heat flux, sensible heat flux and latent heat flux over heterogeneous landscape.
challenges: Regionalization of the net radiation heat flux, soil heat flux, sensible heat flux and latent heat flux over heterogeneous landscape is not an easy issue. The parameterization methodology presented in this research is still in developing stage due to only a single set of values at a specific time of specific day are used in this research. To reach more accurate regional land surface heat fluxes over the Tibetan Plateau area, more field observations, more accurate radiation transfer models to determine the surface reflectance and surface temperature, and another satellites such as GMS (Geo-stationary Meteorological Satellite), ATSR (Along Track Scanning Radiometer) and AVHRR (Advanced Very High-Resolution Radiometer) have to be used.
methods: Four images of MODIS data (30 January 2007, 15 April 2007, 1 August 2007 and 25 October 2007) were used in this study for the comparison among winter, spring, summer and autumn. The derived results were also validated by using the “ground truth” measured in the stations of the Tibetan Observation and Research Platform (TORP).
dataset: Four images of MODIS data (30 January 2007, 15 April 2007, 1 August 2007 and 25 October 2007) were used in this study for the comparison among winter, spring, summer and autumn. In situ data observed in nine stations of Haibei, Maqu, D105, Amdo, NPAM, BJ, NAMOR, QOMS, and SETS in the Tibetan Observation and Research Platform (TORP) are used for the validation.
findings: The results show that the derived surface variables (surface reflectance and surface temperature) and surface heat fluxes (net radiation flux, soil heat flux, sensible heat flux and latent heat flux) in four different seasons over the Tibetan Plateau area are in good accordance with the land surface status. The estimated land surface variables and surface heat fluxes are in good agreement with the ground measurements, and all their absolute percent difference (APD) is less than 10 % in the validation sites. It is therefore concluded that the proposed methodology is successful for the retrieval of land surface variables and surface heat fluxes using the MODIS and in situ data over the Tibetan Plateau area. Compared with the field measurements, the proposed methodology has been proved to be a better approach to getting related land surface heat fluxes over heterogeneous landscape.

Definition.Question: What does 'in-situ data' mean in the context of atmospheric and environmental observations on the Tibetan Plateau?
Definition.Answer: In-situ data refers to measurements and observations collected directly at the location of interest, such as the Tibetan Plateau, using instruments and sensors placed on-site. This type of data provides detailed and localized information about atmospheric and environmental variables like heat fluxes, CO2 concentrations, and boundary layer characteristics.

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'parameterization methodology' in the context of deriving surface heat fluxes over the Tibetan Plateau?
Definition.Answer: Parameterization methodology in this context refers to a process that uses a combination of satellite data (such as MODIS) and in-situ measurements to estimate and model surface variables and heat fluxes over the heterogeneous landscape of the Tibetan Plateau. This approach helps in capturing the regional distribution of these fluxes, which are otherwise challenging to measure directly across large areas.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods used for meteorological observations at the Everest Atmospheric and Environmental Comprehensive Observation Station compare to those employed in the Tibetan Observation and Research Platform?
Comparison.Answer: The Everest station relies on methods such as artificial rain gauge and evaporation pan observations, alongside routine meteorological data collection. The Tibetan Observation and Research Platform (TORP) uses in-situ data from multiple stations and also integrates advanced systems like ABL tower, GPS radio-sonde, and Wind Profiler and RASS for a comprehensive atmospheric analysis.

Interpretation.Question: What data collection methods might be inferred as crucial for understanding the interactions between the land surface and atmosphere over the Tibetan Plateau?
Interpretation.Answer: The crucial data collection methods inferred include in-situ observations from various instruments like GPS radio-sonde systems, Wind Profilers, RASS, and sonic turbulent measurement systems, which are essential for capturing atmospheric and soil variables, the structure of the Atmospheric Boundary Layer (ABL), and atmospheric turbulence characteristics over the Tibetan Plateau.

Interpretation.Question: How might the challenges of regionalizing surface heat fluxes over heterogeneous landscapes be addressed through data collection and processing methods?
Interpretation.Answer: These challenges might be addressed by utilizing a combination of satellite data (e.g., MODIS, GMS, ATSR, AVHRR) and in-situ observations from multiple field stations to improve the accuracy of radiation transfer models and derive surface reflectance and temperature. This combined approach supports the parameterization methodology for regionalizing surface heat fluxes over heterogeneous landscapes.

Interpretation.Question: What factors should be considered when interpreting the diurnal and seasonal variations of surface heat fluxes over the Tibetan Plateau from observational data?
Interpretation.Answer: Factors to consider include the elevation and clear atmospheric conditions of the Tibetan Plateau, which contribute to larger downward shortwave radiation. The variations in turbulent fluxes during dry and wet periods, as well as the daily heating patterns of the land surface, are also influential. These factors are critical in understanding the energy exchange processes and atmospheric boundary layer dynamics observed over different seasons.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the difficulty in understanding and modeling the complete energy and water cycles over the Tibetan Plateau?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The lack of quantitative understanding of interactions between the land surface and atmosphere makes it challenging to model the complete energy and water cycles. This difficulty is compounded by limited experiments to determine land and atmospheric parameters, with most investigations being conducted only in summer and at a few locations.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is regionalization of the net radiation heat flux, soil heat flux, sensible heat flux, and latent heat flux over heterogeneous landscapes challenging?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Regionalization of these fluxes is challenging due to the developing stage of the parameterization methodology, which relies on a single set of values at specific times. Achieving more accurate regional land surface heat fluxes requires more field observations, improved radiation transfer models, and data from additional satellites.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the obvious diurnal variations in radiation and surface heat fluxes over the Tibetan Plateau?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The diurnal variations are influenced by the higher elevation and clear atmosphere of the Tibetan Plateau, leading to larger downward shortwave radiation compared to other areas. The land surface is a strong heating source during the day and a weak heating sink at night, contributing to these variations.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the consequences of using in-situ data collection methods for understanding the atmospheric boundary layer (ABL) structure over the Tibetan Plateau?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using in-situ data collection methods allows for detailed analysis of the ABL structure, such as the characteristics of atmospheric and soil variables, and atmospheric turbulent structures. These methods provide precise measurements that contribute to understanding diurnal variations and the extension of the ABL, which can reach almost 3 km above the ground surface and is characterized by a well-mixed layer of potential temperature.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary objective of collecting atmospheric and environmental data at high altitudes on the Tibetan Plateau, such as through comprehensive observation stations?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objective is to understand the interactions between the land surface and atmosphere, which is crucial for modeling the complete energy and water cycles over the Tibetan Plateau and their effects on global climate change. This is important due to the plateau's significant influence on atmospheric circulations over China, eastern Asia, and the globe.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the intentions behind monitoring the diurnal and seasonal variations of atmospheric and soil variables on the Tibetan Plateau?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The intention is to analyze the characteristics of land surface heat fluxes, CO2 flux partitioning, and the atmospheric boundary layer structure. These analyses help in understanding how the plateau functions as a significant heat source and sink, which is critical for grasping the dynamics of atmospheric and surface interactions in this high-altitude region.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are implemented to ensure the accuracy and reliability of the meteorological data collected from the observation station on the Tibetan Plateau?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The meteorological data from the observation station is carefully collected by following strict instrument operation protocols. Any obvious error data is removed during data processing to ensure accuracy and reliability.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How does the use of in-situ data from the Tibetan Observation and Research Platform (TORP) help in analyzing the atmospheric boundary layer characteristics over the Tibetan Plateau?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: In-situ data from TORP is crucial for analyzing the atmospheric boundary layer characteristics, as it provides detailed observations from tools like the ABL tower, GPS radio-sonde system, and Wind Profiler and RASS, enabling a comprehensive understanding of the atmospheric turbulent structure and potential temperature variations.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methodologies are employed to derive regional surface heat fluxes over the Tibetan Plateau using satellite data and field measurements?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: A parameterization methodology based on MODIS data and in-situ observations is employed to derive regional surface heat fluxes. The methodology involves using satellite-derived surface variables and validating them against ground-truth measurements from field stations, ensuring accuracy in the representation of surface heat fluxes over heterogeneous landscapes.

Enablement.Question: What conditions or technologies enabled the establishment of comprehensive atmospheric and environmental observation stations in high-altitude regions like the Tibetan Plateau?
Enablement.Answer: The establishment of comprehensive observation stations such as the one on Mt. Qomolangma was enabled by the need to understand atmosphere-land interactions in the Himalayas, which involve complex atmospheric circulation systems like mountain-valley winds and glacier winds. The high elevation of the Tibetan Plateau, which significantly absorbs solar radiation and experiences dramatic seasonal changes, also necessitated the development of these stations to observe and analyze atmospheric and environmental variables in this unique region.

Enablement.Question: How does the integration of in-situ data with remote sensing technologies enable the derivation of regional surface heat fluxes in heterogeneous landscapes?
Enablement.Answer: The integration of in-situ data with remote sensing technologies like MODIS allows for the derivation of regional surface heat fluxes over heterogeneous landscapes by providing detailed measurements of surface reflectance and temperature. This combination enhances the accuracy of estimating net radiation flux, soil heat flux, sensible heat flux, and latent heat flux, as validated by ground measurements in the Tibetan Plateau area.

Enablement.Question: What are the challenges and necessary technological advancements needed to improve the accuracy of land surface heat flux measurements over the Tibetan Plateau?
Enablement.Answer: Challenges in measuring land surface heat flux over the Tibetan Plateau include the need for more accurate radiation transfer models and additional satellite data sources such as GMS, ATSR, and AVHRR. The parameterization methodology is still developing, as it requires more field observations and validation to address the complex regionalization of heat fluxes over heterogeneous landscapes.

Expectation.Question: Why might the data collection methods used in the Tibetan Plateau for atmospheric and land surface interactions be challenging to implement in other high-altitude regions?
Expectation.Answer: The Tibetan Plateau, with its complex terrain and high elevation, significantly influences atmospheric circulations. The challenges in implementing similar data collection methods in other regions might include differences in topography, elevation, and climate, which affect the land-atmosphere interactions and the necessary data collection equipment and techniques.

Expectation.Question: What expectations might researchers have regarding the accuracy and reliability of datasets derived from satellite remote sensing compared to in-situ measurements over the Tibetan Plateau?
Expectation.Answer: Researchers might expect that satellite remote sensing could provide broader regional distribution data, while in-situ measurements offer more precise local data. However, the accuracy and reliability of satellite data may be influenced by the complexity of the landscape and atmospheric conditions, requiring validation with ground-truth data to ensure consistency with expected land surface and atmospheric variables.

Expectation.Question: Why might the integration of multiple observational systems, such as GPS radio-sonde and Wind Profiler, be necessary for understanding the atmospheric boundary layer dynamics over the Tibetan Plateau?
Expectation.Answer: The integration of multiple observational systems is necessary due to the intricate nature of the atmospheric boundary layer over the Tibetan Plateau. The diverse systems provide complementary data that help capture the full structure and dynamics of the boundary layer, including vertical gradients and turbulent characteristics, which are crucial for understanding how the region's unique conditions impact atmospheric processes.

Judgmental.Question: How do you evaluate the effectiveness of using in-situ observations compared to remote sensing data for capturing atmospheric and land surface interactions over the Tibetan Plateau?
Judgmental.Answer: In-situ observations provide detailed local characteristics, such as land surface heat fluxes, CO2 flux partitioning, and atmospheric variables, which are crucial for understanding complex interactions at specific locations. However, remote sensing offers the ability to derive regional distributions of surface heat fluxes over heterogeneous landscapes, allowing for broader analysis. Both methods have their strengths, and a combination of them could enhance the understanding of atmospheric and land interactions.

Additionally, the use of in-situ data and various measurement systems like the ABL tower and sonic turbulent measurement system ensure comprehensive data collection.

Assertion.Answer: The challenges in collecting and modeling the energy and water cycles over the Tibetan Plateau include a lack of quantitative understanding of interactions between the land surface and atmosphere, limited experiments to determine land and atmospheric parameters, and most investigations being conducted only in summer at a few locations. These challenges hinder comprehensive modeling of the complete cycles.

This combined approach allows for validation against ground truth measurements and aids in accurate regionalization of surface heat fluxes, as demonstrated by the parameterization methodology mentioned in the papers.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore potential challenges in the regionalization of land surface heat fluxes over heterogeneous landscapes of the Tibetan Plateau using remote sensing data.
Request/Directive.Answer: The regionalization of land surface heat fluxes over the Tibetan Plateau using remote sensing data faces challenges due to the complex and heterogeneous landscape. The parameterization methodology is still developing, requiring more field observations and accurate radiation transfer models. The current approach uses MODIS data and in-situ data for validation, but it is limited by single-time observations and specific satellite data, suggesting the need for additional satellite resources like GMS, ATSR, and AVHRR.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify and discuss the potential datasets that could be used to validate remote sensing data for studying energy and water cycles over the Tibetan Plateau.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential datasets for validating remote sensing data include in-situ observations from the Tibetan Observation and Research Platform (TORP), which provide ground truth measurements of surface reflectance and temperature, as well as net radiation, soil heat, sensible heat, and latent heat fluxes. These datasets are crucial for ensuring the accuracy of remote sensing-derived variables and their alignment with actual land surface conditions across different seasons.
